description: Zac Poonen shares his heart plainly at a christian conference. He speaks on true discipleship and those that follow Christ and don't gather men and honor to themselves. This message is throbbing with love and unselfish desire yet has a strong rebuke and correction for many in ministry. May God allow this message to be a balm to many before that great day before God in heaven where all things will be made bare.

(Genesis) - Part 10
description: The three arks of Scripture typify God's protection from death.  As Noah built an ark, what priority do we give to the only thing that will last after the world is destroyed, namely the Church?  The raven and the dove are pictures of the flesh and the Spirit that show what our true spiritual condition is.

title: (Genesis) - Part 13
description: God is still looking for people like Abraham today who have a responsive heart.  The blessing of Abraham--the baptism in the Holy Spirit--can make us a blessing to every family that we meet.  Abraham's mistakes serve a sober warning to us that missing God's will that it may go well with us have serious and long lasting consequences long after God has forgiven us of the sin.

title: (Genesis) - Part 15
description: Melchizedek teaches us that we don't always bless by giving big sermons; two or three appropriate sentences can be all it takes to stir up faith in someone else.  One revelation from God protected Abraham from the temptations from the king of Sodom.  Faith is hearing God's promise to you and "amening" that as Abraham did.

title: (Genesis) - Part 17
description: Abraham was a man God picked out because he was quick to obey clear revelation and showed hospitality and true humility as a servant.  He also was careful to raise up a family in God-fearing ways.  This first recorded intercessory prayer reveals that God's ear is open to one righteous life.

title: (Genesis) - Part 22
description: What Abraham gave to Isaac was not a doctrine but a living faith.  The struggle of Jacob and Esau in the womb depicts the struggle in the believer between flesh and spirit.  God's sovereign choice of Jacob was not according to works, which has principles of rest for us, such as being delivered from competition and jealousy over ministry with others in the church.  Isaac's partiality at age 80 is a warning to be steadfast to the spiritual zeal of younger years.

title: (Genesis) - Part 25
description: Testing and breaking is the way of God in dealing with every true man of God.  God trained Jacob in submission through a difficult father-in-law and circumstances.  Like Jacob, God always wrestles to bring us down to a zero point of brokenness, where we only want to hold onto Him.

title: (Genesis) - Part 4
description: God gave Adam two gardens to tend and guard: a natural one and a spiritual one with his wife.  Brother Zac touches on problems in marriage that come about by veering off God's original purpose.  When God makes two one, Satan is sure to come to break up the union through temptation.  This original lie and temptation is alive and well today, whenever we seek to be a mini-god to others and seeking to get other people to admire us.

title: (Genesis) - Part 8
description: The rise of 5 things from Cain's descendants--city life, perpetuating one's name, immorality, musical instruments and industry--are dangers to be alert to in our day.  Enoch demonstrates a godly life in the midst of death, showing how a man can walk with God and still have a large family and be a lonely preacher of righteousness.  Enoch is a picture of the Bride that's going to be raptured when Jesus comes again.

title: (God Can Solve Every Problem - 3) Lame Man Healed
description: The lame man at the pool of Bethesda depicts one who has life but cannot walk--a life of fellowship with God and victory over sin.  His 38 years in that condition points to the 38 years of Israel's wilderness wandering--a life under the law of struggling forever to please God.  The good news is that behind every command of Jesus is the grace and power to do it!

title: (God Can Solve Every Problem - 6) Blind Man's Eyes Opened
description: Zac presents what some possible underlying meanings of anointing with clay on the blind man's eyes that transcended theology to have a testimony and seeing the realities of eternity.  Not all division is of the devil, for God tests people whether they will stand up for they know to be the truth; and those that do will have their eyes opened more and more.

title: (God Can Solve Every Problem) Lazarus raised from the dead
(God Can Solve Every Problem) Miraculous catch of fish
(God Can Solve Every Problem) Multitude fed
(God Can Solve Every Problem) Royal official's Son healed
(God Can Solve Every Problem) Walking on water
(God Can Solve Every Problem) Water turned into wine
description: Zac Poonen begins this 8-part series analyzing the spiritual message and purpose behind the Lord's miracle of the water turned into wine.  "When the Lord tells you to do something," he explains, "you act on that and you find a miracle takes place as you do it."  Zac draws several wonderful contrasts in the Christian life--law and grace, coworkers with God and slothful servants, self-satisfaction and neediness, the Spirit's anointing and a dried up life.

(Guidelines) Illumination I
description: McGee delights in how limitless the voice of the Spirit in the Bible is. Not even great Bible scholars can discover these treasures in a whole lifetime.

title: (Guidelines) Illumination II
description: Reminding how the Spirit of God wrote through men, without error, yet without destroying their personality. The Bible is the “hidden” mysteries of God written down through men.

title: (Guidelines) In What Way Is the Bible Unique
description: McGee points out the paradox that the Bible has “dual” authorship.  While the ultimate author is God, many different men were used to write the Bible. He draws comparisons to the God/Man authorship of the Bible to the Word becoming flesh in Jesus Christ. He affirms both the divinity and humanity of the Bible as important to reach mankind.

title: (Guidelines) Inspiration I
description: The importance of understanding that all scripture is “God-Breathed”.   He makes sure to note that it’s not the mere thoughts that are inspired…but the very WORDS. (For it is WRITTEN…)

title: (Guidelines) Inspiration II
description: This sermon continues to point out that it is the very words of Scripture that are inspired, and not just the thoughts behind them.

title: (Guidelines) Interpretation I
description: A look at correct interpretation of scripture. He notes, in the Bible publishing market, that there is a difference between translations and paraphrases.

title: (Guidelines) Interpretation II
description: A look at what makes a good intepretation of the Bible. He warns that he can not recommend modern versions of the Bible, because of the presence of doctrinal or cultural biases from the translators. Still he values them as “interpretations” useful for occasional cross reference. In the end he has the highest confidence in the Authroized Version, and the Scofield Study Bible.

title: (Guidelines) Introduction
description: This is not a Bible message, but a very brief introduction to J Veron McGee’s radio ministry.

title: (Guidelines) Is the Bible Important
description: Beginning with an affirmation that ALL of the Bible is the Word of God, McGee recalls how he had to mature from reading it piece meal to reading it through. He exhorts us to read the Bible through all 66 books. In fact, this was the mission for His radio ministry, “Through the Bible” in which he took listeners through every chapter and almost every verse of the Bible over the course of 5 years.

title: (Guidelines) Meditate on the Bible
description: The Word of God is to be before His children continually. We should write the word on our doorposts, and the gates of our homes, and everywhere we live. McGee recalls a conversation he had with an advertising executive from Coca Cola about how serious the world is in reinforcing its message everywhere. In practical ways he suggests using car travel time, or bedtime for additional Bible time.

title: (Guidelines) Obey the Bible
description: One of the most obvious guidelines to the Bible…obey it! Obedience is essential to an understanding of the Bible. Examples from scripture, to show us how we have no right to expect God to talk to us if we do not have ‘obedience that comes from faith.’ Either the Bible will keep us from sin, or sin will keep us from the Bible.

title: (Guidelines) Pass It On To Others
description: After we read, study, meditate, obey, we should pass it on to others. He notes that we will reach a ‘saturation point’ in studying the Bible without sharing what we have learned. We must exhort others with what we have learned in the scriptures. Sharing the Word of God is a powerful way to learn it ourselves.

title: (Guidelines) Pratical Ways To Learn The Bible
description: 7 Guidelines, taken from the Psalms, to follow in learning the Word of God. He likens following these guidelines to following the directions on a bottle of medicine, in order to get the most benefit.

title: (Guidelines) Preservation
description: Marveling over the preservation of the Bible through various attempts to destroy it throughout history. Despite it burnings or bannings the Bible remains one of the best selling books of all time.

title: (Guidelines) Proof That The Bible Is The Word Of God
description: A brief introduction to a study on internal and external proofs that the Bible is the Word of God. (Note that the body of the message is not included here.)

title: (Guidelines) Read What Others Say
description: Practical advice to read the bible commentaries of reliable teachers. While reminding us to be discerning, McGee affirms the importance of what other studious men of God have discovered in the Bible, for our own studies.

title: (Guidelines) Read the Bible
description: If you want to know the God of the Bible, then read the Bible. Our “ears must be attentive”, even if we must determine to read through a passage many times for it to speak to us. McGee also affirms the value of quality preaching and teaching of the Word of God in Church.

title: (Guidelines) Revelation
description: A look at the phenomena of Revelation from God to man.  He used Helen Keller’s autobiographical comments of how understanding came to her all at once, to explain how spiritually blind and deaf mankind is being communicated to by God. He goes on to explain that God can use creation, experiences, our hearts, and above all, the Bible to speak to us. He ends this sermon with a strong affirmation of the reliability of the Bible. He quotes B. B. Warfield. “The Bible is the Word of God in such a sense, that whatever it says, God says.”

title: (Guidelines) Spirit of God Makes It Real
description: McGee recalls that early in his ministry he was an ‘apologetics preacher’ but in later years he moved away from this emphasis. He explains this by observing that apologetics are helpful to helping a person believe the Bible is the Word of God, but only the Spirit can allow a person to know this. He reemphasizes this point by saying that we can’t rely on biblical archaeology or science to confirm the Word of God…the Holy Spirit must become real to us.

title: (Guidelines) Study the Bible
description: A simple straight forward plead to study the bible systematically, with diligence. He uses the account of Phillip explaining the scriptures to the inquisitive Ethiopian as an example as to why intelligent understanding of the bible is important.

title: (Guidelines) Transformed Lives
description: McGee observes that one of the evidences that the bible is the Word of God is it’s power to transform lives. (Note: This recording is truncated.)

title: (Heavenly Vision) 1 - The necessity of Heavenly Vision
(Heavenly Vision) 2 - The two aspects of the Vision
(Hosea) Reaping the Whirlwind
description: The Lord pronounced judgement against the nation of Isral and against it's capital city Samaria.  Hosea likened the nation to an unturned pancake, burnt on one side towards the world and undone or unprepared toward the Lord, hence they were good for nothing neither hot nor cold like the church of Laodicea in Revelation 3.  By this time in their history Israel had become established in their sin and had set up their own ungodly rulers.  Even though they continued to sacrifice to the Lord the Lord no longer accepted the sacrifices as they were given from an unrepentant heart. The southern nation of Judah now tursted in their fortified cities but these cities could not save them from the judgement of God.  These prophecies were given at a time of great material prosperity in the nation of Israel when the people must have thought that the Lord was blessing them but didn't care that their hearts were foul towards Him.

title: (Hosea) True Wisdom Turns Us Back to God
description: Israel had been greatly blessed by the Lord and yet as is the way with fallen man at times when the Lord is blessing us most our heart is far from Him, they had engaged in Baal worship and had even gone far enough as to worship Molech, which involved child sacrifice.  They had sent the Lord a message with their actions by showing they would only turn to Him when times where bad, so the Lord promised judgement so they would cry out to Him to save them once more.  The Lord makes great promises of deliverence to Israel even going so far as to say He will conquer death but if they would not turn to Him then they would go into exhile. The book of Hosea ends though not with judgement but with a great proclamation of the grace of God and that how if we would turn to Him with our whole hearts then He will shower us with His great mercies.

description: Milton Green shares a very strong penetrating message about the state of the church in the modern day. The devil and the powers of darkness have been having much control and infiltration into the church in the modern day. A much needed message to hear of things to come.

title: (Isaiah) Hope In the Midst of Judgment
(Isaiah) How to Prepare for God’s Judgment
(Isaiah) Judgment and Praise in the Great Tribulation
(Isaiah) The Blessing of Looking to the Lord
(Isaiah) The Cause & Cure of Spiritual Blindness
(Isaiah) The Glory of the Messiah’s Character
(Isaiah) The Glory of the Messiah’s Reign
(Isaiah) What to Hang Your Life On
(Joel) Come, Let Us Return to the Lord
(Joel) The Day of the Lord Brings Judah Low
(John 15 #1) I Am the True Vine
description: "Unless God convinces you you're not the Vine," says Ed Miller, "you're going to try to be the Vine."  When so much of the Church is on life support, Christ is to be the Christian's environment--our air, our food, our drink, our rest.

title: (John 15 #2) Abiding and Fruitfulness
description: Ed Miller exposes common problems Christians fall into--a growth that is merely external, not internal life that comes from God Himself.  We get off target when we put our eyes on growth.  Brother Ed shows that if you will feed on Christ, you will grow like the lily grows--growing but never concerning itself about its growth.

title: (John 15 #3) The Husbandman
description: "What is pruning?" asks Ed Miller.  "It's seeing Christ in the Word of God, and every revelation of Christ liberates you and sets you free."  The Father as the husbandman knows exactly what He is doing to see that the image of the Parent is stamped upon the child.

title: (John) The Tabernacle of God is With Men
(John) When God Became One Of Us
(Laying Hold On Eternity) Knowing God As Our Father
(Laying Hold On Eternity) Knowing Jesus As Our Lord
(Laying Hold On Eternity) Knowing The Holy Spirit As Our Helper
(Living Sacrifice) 10. Let Me See Thy Face And Die
(Living Sacrifice) 7. I Come To The Light
(Luke) 03 - Unbelief-Faith
description: Ed Miller continues his study of unbelief vs. faith by re-emphasizing some key points. . With certainty, we will all experience moments of unbelief. Yet, be assured that God's will is not hindered by our unbelief, but it can rob us of the blessing. But, in hope, we can always turn to Him that continues to form simple, childlike faith in us as we follow our Saviour, our Teacher and the Hope of all mankind.

title: (Luke) 04 - Unbelief-Faith Of Mary
description: In contrast to Zacharias' unbelief, he now presents Mary's faith and shows her to be a perfect model of the Church. She responds to the angel's pronouncement with child-like faith, with complete and total surrender and is a picture of humility. She is trusting that God the Father will form Christ in her. In the same way, His Church is to surrender and believe that He, by the power of the Holy Spirit, will produce the same miracle of forming the Christian life in us.

title: (Luke) 06 - Songs Of Mary & Zacharias
description: Ed closes out chapter one pointing out Luke's strong emphasis on the Holy Spirit.  John the Baptizer pictures ministry, beginning with the Holy Spirit and being a forerunner for Jesus to follow after.  Mary is a picture of the Church and missions--bringing Christ to the world.  Elizabeth illustrates fellowship and Zacharias the restoration the Lord works after a time of unbelief.

title: (Luke) 07 - Greatness Of His Coming
description: Our over familiarity with the Christmas story can make the powerful truth of it become "la la la".  Brother Ed shows the picture of God's infinite condescension in becoming a baby--the Bread of Life (Jesus) being laid out in a dish (manger) in the House of Bread (Bethlehem) for anyone to partake!  No less than 100 million angels worshiped the Son as He made His first appearance into the world as the Son of all mankind.

title: (Luke) 08 - He Comes To Seekers
description: Jesus came for all mankind, both Jew and Gentile, but in a special way to those who seek Him.  The shepherds represent people who get the light of God from heaven and run to Jesus.  Simeon illustrates the role of the Holy Spirit in any seeking, God's providential timing, and the assurance that no one who seeks Christ dies without Christ.

title: (Luke) 09 - Results Of His Coming
description: What were the results of Jesus' first coming?  It was great joy (the shepherds), contentment in life and tranquility in death (Simeon), rejection (Mary) and testimony and witness (Anna).  Joseph and Mary losing Jesus at Passover, one of the most religious times of worship and fellowship, serves as a sober reminder that we too can get preoccupied with other things and lose fellowship with Him.

title: (Luke) 10 - Intro To Chap3
description: Although John the Baptizer was a fulfillment of Elijah, the Lord Jesus spoke of the fulfillment of Elijah yet coming.  In light of future prophecy, Ed Miller points out, "Everything God says about the future is designed to teach you the Lord now."  John the Baptizer as a forerunner provides a model of Christian ministry in that the best we can do is to prepare the way for the Lord to follow.

title: (Luke) 11 - Baptism Of Christ
description: John the Baptizer as the first forerunner was preacher of the law with a hot message of judgment to get everyone on level ground--to stand before Christ as guilty sinners.  Why did the Holy Spirit come in the picture of a dove at Jesus' baptism?  How does Jesus' genealogy underscore God's genius in the miracle of the virgin birth?  Brother Ed labors to exalt Jesus as the Son of all mankind as he answers these questions and more!

title: (Luke) 16 - Ch4-14 to 9-6 Overview
description: Ed Miller gives an overview of the Lord's ministry, especially noting how He had authority over demons, disease and death.  The miracles themselves are instructive to spiritual realities.  In the healing of the fever of Peter's mother-in-law, the secret of Christian ministry is shown by the Lord touching you in your weakness and giving you supernatural strength to serve.

title: (Luke) 18 - Chap5Cont- Man With Palsy
description: All of the miracles are really parables, a physical illustration of the spiritual side in the Christian life.  Brother Ed shows that when we feel paralyzed and helpless as Christian, it just means we haven't entered into our forgiveness.  "The more we enter into our forgiveness," he says, "the freer we become."  Many other truths are drawn from this account, such as an expose of the Pharisees, obstacles of coming to Jesus, and evangelism.

title: (Luke) 19 - Levi's Banquet & Grain Fields
description: What is the Christian life?  The text from Luke's gospel illustrates it as a wedding (not a funeral) and the joy of strolling with Jesus in the grain fields and allowing Him to satisfy your hunger.  Christianity is not a bunch of rules and regulations of the legalists who think it's all about what you believe and how well you behave.  It's Who you know and how much you enjoy Him.

title: (Luke) 21 - Centurion & Widow Of Nain
description: The Sermon on the Plain describes what my life will increasingly look like when Jesus has undisputed lordship.  Go after Christ, not the rules, and the good fruit will be produced.  In the account of the widow of Nain, Christ is lord over man's most unsolvable problem: death.  If Jesus can solve the greatest problem, we can be sure He can solve every lesser problem in our lives!

title: (Luke) 22 - Doubts Of John The Baptist
description: Some lessons we can learn here is that when we have doubts, send them to Jesus.  We should also never judge the reality by outward appearances.  Though Jesus never visited John in prison, He had a high regard for him, and we can expect in our trials at times not to hear, "Well done, good and faithful servant," down here.  There is a difference between doubting (struggling faith) and disbelieving, and the good news is that God accepts struggling faith as faith.

title: (Luke) 23 - Anointing Jesus Feet
description: How can we love the Lord Jesus and be freed from a cold heart?  It's by entering into how much we've been forgiven.  Brother Ed shows from the devotion and love of the sinful woman how it is impossible to embarrass the Lord and you don't have to defend yourself of the criticisms of others.

title: (Luke) 27 - Sending Out Of The Twelve
description: Jesus sends the twelve forth on a 'graduate course' in ministry that lasted six months to a year.  To defuse the 'look what we did' mentality, Christ sets up the feeding of five thousand to drive the message home that they didn't do it, but it was Him doing it through them.  The twelve baskets of crumbs gathered up teach us that Jesus is more than enough for what we will ever face!

title: (Luke) 30 - Missions-Luke10
description: One of the greatest chapters on missions, Luke 10 teaches us not to rejoice in what we do but in Who we know.  The point of the parable of the Good Samaritan is not, "Help your neighbor," but one of character: who are you?  Mary becomes the example of the gospel by sitting at Jesus' feet as a receiver.  To Martha, Jesus was the honored guest; to Mary, He was the host.

title: (Luke) 33 - Outworkings Of Prayer Cont
description: Jesus is infinitely stronger than Satan, and He casts him out by the finger of God, which is the Spirit of God.  The one who gets the Holy Spirit is the one who asks for Him.  The blessedness of the Virgin Mary after the natural is not to be compared to the infinitely higher blessedness of being related to Jesus through the Word of God.

title: (Luke) 34 - The Sign Of Jonah
description: Ed ties together the sign of Jonah to the resurrected Christ living in us in connection with this great prayer chapter.  If we can have a single eye on the Lord--not on many things like missions and family and witnessing--then our whole body will be full of light and the world will see Jesus in us--the sign of Jonah.  What the world needs is more Christians praying the Lord's Prayer in reality.

title: (Luke) 36 - Dressed In Readiness
description: What will one's life look like who is experiencing Life and focused on eternity?  Ed debunks some erroneous views of readiness being synonymous with Christian busyness.  My lamp is lit when I'm being faithful to the stewardship I've been given.  The message concludes with the miracle of the humped-over woman as an invitation to Sabbath rest in the Lord to walk uprightly before Him.

title: (Luke) 37 - Kingdom Of God-Chap13
description: "The Lord can undo in a moment of time," Ed points out from the miracle of the bent over woman, "years of bondage."  The real message is not to try to be upright by works but to let the Lord touch you.  The next two parables (the mustard seed & the leaven) illustrate how the kingdom of God works.  Though leaven is often a picture of sin and corruption, in its context here is a symbol of the Holy Spirit that keeps on working through the whole "lump of dough" until it's completely transformed.

title: (Luke) 38 - Kingdom Of God Conclusion
description: The kingdom of God teachings close with a sermon on the narrow door whose point is, "Don't worry about how many are saved; you just make sure you're ready."  Seekers find the Lord--always!  Jesus healing the man with dropsy is the climax of the Sabbath miracles picturing man being held and embraced by God.

title: (Luke) 39 - Salvation-What It Means To Man
description: God's salvation is unconditional grace, set in contrast to the works-mentality of the religion of the Pharisees.  The invitation to God's banquet is to the humble (not the proud) and reveals the generous heart of the Lord.  The parable of counting the cost and the king going to battle contrasts once again the religion of the Pharisees of bills and fights with exclusive devotion to Jesus to supply all the resources we need to build and every victory in the fight.

title: (Luke) 42 - Encouraging Faith
description: Verses 1-10 of Luke 17 serve as a warning of being a stumbling block of discouraging faith in the little ones (Christians) that trust in Jesus.  The important thing about faith is the Object of your faith; faith lays hold of God who does impossible things!  Ed shows from the healing of the ten lepers that the one who returned emphasizes the heart obedience that blesses Christ as contrasted with the nine who only followed the letter of the command.

title: (Luke) 43 - The Unjust Judge
description: The way Jesus comes is the way He always comes--by revelation.  Ed shares how "one of the days" of the Son of Man differs from THE day of the Lord.  Just like those common ordinary days of Noah and Lot, as you're just doing the most common thing, Christ will dawn on you.  The parable of the unjust judge teaches us always to trust and look at God's heart, not His actions, and by misjudging Him end up fainting.

title: (Luke) 44 - The Mercy Of God
description: The parable of the Pharisee and the publican teaches that those who trust in themselves will not be justified.  The infants brought to the Lord Jesus pictured the helpless dependence of those fall helplessly into the arms of Christ for salvation.  The rich young ruler demonstrates the hopelessness of works to be saved, but is a mighty miracle of God, as miraculous as a camel (the largest animal of Palestine) going through the eye of a needle (the smallest opening).

title: (Luke) 47 - Trinity-Parable Of The Pound
description: Ed analyzes the parable of the pound (or mina) as contrasted with Matthew's parable of the talent as the summary of Jesus' teaching ministry.  The most important part of the second coming is not the second coming but on the One who is coming again.

title: (Luke) 48 - Palm Sunday-Luke19
description: In the Lord's triumphal entry into Jerusalem, we see both the cross and the crown.  In several ways it truly was a triumphal entry (though veiled), for in foretaste it pictured Jesus as the Lord of the universe, the one who tames creation, and His coming as the King.  Yet it also was a "non-triumphal" entry, as evidenced by His appearing on a humble donkey and His anguished weeping over the city.

title: (Luke) 49 - Cleansing Of The Temple-Chap19
description: Ed offers 4 observations to aid in understanding this second cleansing of the temple, such as seeing it in light of Jeremiah 7, contrasting the outer glory with the inner corruption, and studying the background of the convenience animals.  Jesus weeps over externalism, looking to Him in a lighthearted way, worldliness, mixture, and prejudice.  He comes to flip over everything in our lives that is not Christ, then He can begin to teach us.

title: (Luke) 50 - Trinity Revelation-Patience-Image Of God
description: Ed examines the first 3 of 5 clashes between Jesus and the religious leaders (in chapter 20) from two viewpoints: from the level of earth and from the heart of God.  Bigger than the question of authority is the principle of revelation.  Christ will always be silent to those who do not seriously want to know the truth.  In the parable of the wicked vinedressers, though it pictures the judgment upon unfaithful Israel, more than that it pictures the amazing longsuffering of God.

title: (Luke)01 - Introduction
description: In the first part of his introduction, Ed Miller presents Luke in the context of the Bible. As the only Gentile author, Luke offers a unique perspective and Ed begins by outlining six main themes. He begins with Jesus' own pronouncement of Himself as the Son of Man, continues with His compassion for the downtrodden and through His relationship with women and children, He is presented as an impartial God who is truly the Saviour of all mankind.

(Revelations Of The Gospel) 1. A Revelation Of Self
description: The Gospel is like a Crystal, with many different colored lights shinning out of the same gem.  Some look at the Crystal and say it is green, and others say "no its red."  But the mature one walks around the Crystal and says "your both right" It is the same with the gospel in the scriptures.  There are many different ingredients that make up the recipe of the gospel.  This series attempts to show all the ingredients of the gospel.  This is important because if our recipe is different than Gods, then we will not get the same result found in the book of Acts.

description: The Gospel is like a Crystal, with many different colored lights shinning out of the same gem.  Some look at the Crystal and say it is green, and others say "no its red." (Sabbath Miracles) 02 - Unclean Spirit
description: Jesus' casting out the unclean spirit shows what a "Sabbath surrender" is all about.  "Anything that is not the fullness of the Holy Spirit," says brother Ed, "can be included under unclean spirit, and we need to be delivered."  The healing of fever has a message for us about rest and service.  Christian service is designed by God in Sabbath truth to be spontaneous, from natural weakness to supernatural strength, and a byproduct of union with Him.

title: (Sabbath Miracles) 03 - Bethesda John 5
description: The healing of the lame man is a picture of Sabbath liberty, a life free from condemnation.  Growth in this liberty generates conflict, for true heart obedience resembles disobedience in the eyes of the religious.

title: (Sabbath Miracles) 04 - Withered Hand Blind
description: The withered hand is hand shriveled, cut off, unusable and paralyzed; that is how we are trying to obey God's commandments in our power.  We need a perpetual miracle as we look into Jesus' face and He works a mighty miracle by the power of God for every obedience.  The man born blind shows that Sabbath vision is when you see Jesus bigger and bigger and fellowship with Him outside the camp.

title: (Sabbath Miracles) 05 - Humped Woman Dropsy
description: The body of the humped over woman pictures a life bound looking at the things of earth and unable to walk uprightly before God.  This miracle depicts Sabbath victory by bringing your burden to the Lord.  The clincher miracle, the healing of the man with dropsy, pictures the hug of Jesus to set us free from who we are--poison all through our system that bloats our flesh and discolors our appearance.

(Spiritual Fullness #1) Come to Me and Drink
description: "You've been designed by God," teaches Ernie Hile, "to live in spiritual fullness."  Are you being satisfied with something other than the Lord Jesus, or are you seeking for practical ways to take Him up on His offer to come to Him and drink and experience those rivers of living water?  (This message was delivered at Harvey-Cedars Conference 2006)

title: (Spiritual Guidelines for Courtship) Godly Weddings
description: What does a Godly wedding look like? Who should be involved in the process of planning a wedding? Brother Mose gives Biblical principles and practical advice to all who are involved in planning and preparing a God-honoring, Christ-centered wedding.

title: (Spiritual Guidelines for Courtship) Practical Courtship Issues
description: There are often many questions surrounding the courtship process. When is a young person ready to consider courtship? How should a young man begin? How should a courting couple relate to one another and to others? In this message, Brother Rick steps through the courtship process answering these and many similar questions along the way.

title: (Spiritual Guidelines for Courtship) Preparing for Courtship
description: How should youth prepare themselves for courtship? How can parents prepare their children for courtship? What are the differences between courtship, betrothal, and dating? Brother Rick draws on many principles from the Word of God and years of experience as a pastor and father to give sound answers to these questions and many others.

title: (Spiritual Guidelines for Courtship) Questions and Answers on Courtship
description: This message is a collection of several question and answer sessions in which Brother Rick attempted to answer many of the specific questions that we have concerning courtship.

title: (Spiritual Guidelines for Courtship) Testimonies of Godly Courtship
description: Does courtship really work? Are the blessings as great as the preachers make them sound? Listen as five couples give their testimonies of how the Lord brought them together, the beautiful ways that God worked in their lives to prepare them for courtship, the joy of honoring their authorities, the blessing of hands-off courtship, and much more.

title: (Spiritual Guidelines for Courtship) The Courtship Relationship
description: In this message Brother Rick gives several key building blocks that are important to the proper flow of a courtship. Courtship is essentially a relational process, and so it is vital that not only the relationship between the couple is properly developed and maintained, but also between them and their parents, their church, and God.

title: (Spiritual Preparedness #1) The Remnant Church
description: The remnant church is pictured in John on his face before a vision of the risen Savior by the Holy Spirit.  "If I'm not seeing Him in this Book now when He makes Himself known now," says brother Ed, "I will not be ready to welcome Him when He comes back."  The only one problem we can have in the Christian life is to take our eyes off the full revelation of Christ in Revelation chapter 1.

title: (Spiritual Preparedness #2) The Spirit's Warning To His Church
description: In the seven churches of Revelation is a warning of seven different possibilities of taking our eyes off the Lord Jesus and not be ready for His coming.  Ephesus starts with the most common way believers take their eyes off Christ through ministry and service and with each church becomes increasingly more subtle.  Brother Ed's burden is to simplify the Scriptures to see God's heart in each warning to stay steadfast to Jesus.

title: (The Aggressive Holy Spirit) The Mystery & Method of Kingdom Growth
(The Aggressive Holy Spirit) What do you do with Immorality?
(The Aggressive Holy Spirit) Word & Spirit: How God Implants Truth
(The Better Covenant) 1 - A Loving Father
description: All of our problems arise from our lack of awareness of God as our Father.  What revolutionizes my life is knowing that the Father loves me as much as He loves Jesus!  The quality of life described in the new covenant is distinctively better than that of the old covenant, as high as Jesus is above Moses.  Living in the superior provision of the new covenant is having a Father as Jesus did, not a policeman full of rules and regulations.

title: (The Better Covenant) 2 - All-Sufficient Grace
description: "Grace is God's power to help us, to see us through every need we could ever face in our life," Zac Poonen proclaims.  Do you find yourself continually defeated by a sin--anger, lust, dirty thoughts?  You need not live a substandard Christian life but can freely enter into what God has promised of His all-sufficient grace that is more than a match for whatever your need or difficulty is!

title: (The Better Covenant) 3 - A Life of Faith
description: "To walk by faith is as much superior to walking by sight as Jesus is higher than Moses," says brother Zac.  In the new covenant we have a better life of faith like Jesus, who overcame all sin and pleased the Father from morning until night.  The root causes of failure to walk by faith are in seeing faith as something in ourselves or working hard to obtain what only God can do.  Zac shares how he tried every doctrine of holiness and failed miserably until he came to see the simplicity of biblical faith--leaning of the human personality in total confidence in God's perfect love for me.

title: (The Better Covenant) 4 - The Spirit's Fullness
description: God sent the Holy Spirit first to set us free from sin on the inside, something which the law could never do.  The Spirit comes to bring those that thirst the same life and power that was exhibited in Jesus Christ.  Are rivers of living water flowing from you or just trickles?  Brother Zac shares from God's Word how the Spirit's fullness is something for every believer.

title: (The Better Covenant) 5 - Satan Defeated
description: One way to tell if you are still living under the old covenant is whether you still fight with human beings.  When Satan was defeated on the cross, believers now war against the real enemy which even the greatest saints of the old covenant could never do.  Beware of certain sins that can bring you into fellowship with the devil, such as pride, lying and anger.

title: (The Better Covenant) 6 - Fellowship in One Body
description: Personal holiness must lead to being built together with others into one body, otherwise it's a deception.  It's not the brothers and sisters of faraway lands that perfects holiness in us, but the one in our local assembly that irritates us or rubs us the wrong way.  Each little church must be an expression of Christ's body, which blends people who are totally different in one by the power of the Holy Spirit.
